node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:
The world’s animals and wildlife are going extinct at a greater rate than at any time in human history. Can technology help turn the tide?

Cover image credit: Yashpal Rathore/Nature Picture Library

node.title: Mass extinction: what can stop it?

Credit: Alamy

node.text:
In America, black people are almost twice more likely to die from covid-19 as white people. Our journalists explain how the pandemic has illuminated systemic racism in America. 

Cover image credit: Getty Images

node.text: Officially, covid-19 has killed 3m people around the world. But statistical modelling from The Economist suggests the number could be as much as four times higher. Cover image: Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: how many people have died?

node.text: Myanmar is on the brink of collapse. Its armed forces are continuing a brutal crackdown—arresting, torturing and killing protesters—as Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar’s de-facto leader, is detained. Our experts answer your questions. Cover image: STR/ Getty Images

node.text: Cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin have been billed as a major disruptor to finance. But digital currencies issued by governments might be even more radical—they may even threaten the future of traditional banking. Cover image: Getty Images

node.title: Could digital currencies put banks out of business?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 20, 2021. May be an image of map and text that says 'China now shares trade with far more countries than America Countries which share greater trade* with: United States China No data 2000t *Gross merchandise trade, exports plus imports tor nearest available Source: IM Direction of Trade Statistics The Economist'.

node.text:
Joe Biden wants to counter China's influence on the global economy by increasing America's own. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
This will require partners. Mr Biden has signalled that his administration views potential co-operation with allies on China as more important than confronting Russia.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
But where America does not lead, its allies seem unlikely to go of their own accord. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Swipe left to see how the number of countries sharing trade with China has changed over time.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Rather than being shaped by America's continuing role, Mr Biden's policy is shaped by China's rise. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
To read why it should instead articulate a broader vision of the world, click on the link in our bio.

May be an image of map and text that says 'China now shares trade with far more countries than America Countries which share greater trade* with: United States China No data 2000t *Gross merchandise trade, exports plus imports tor nearest available Source: IM Direction of Trade Statistics The Economist'.

Photo by The Economist on July 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'China now shares trade with far more countries than America Countries which share greater trade* with: % of global total China 100 75 50 United States 2000 25 05 10 15 0 *Gross merchandise trade, exports plus imports Source: MF Direction of Trade Statistics 20 The Economist'.
Photo by The Economist on July 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Science technology Jeff Bezos goes into space. Has Amazon's founder really made history? ASC'.

node.text:
A few minutes after 1pm Universal Time on Tuesday, Jeff Bezos became the first billionaire in space. Or did he?⁠
⁠
It depends, of course, on your definition of "space". The lower bound of outer space is, by convention, something called the Kármán line. Its exact height varies with atmospheric conditions. ⁠
⁠
Blue Origin's New Shephard rocket launched the capsule on a trajectory that would culminate above an altitude of 100km. The capsule then separated and carried on into space. ⁠
⁠
With Richard Branson claiming the title as the "first billionaire in space" and Elon Musk waiting in the wings, has the Amazon founder really made history? Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the billionaire space race.⁠
⁠
Credit: Tony Gutierrez

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 20, 2021. May be a closeup.

node.text:
Dive deep below the surface of the ocean, where the water changes from blue to black, and you could find this creature.⁠
⁠
Anglerfish are one of many species that survive amidst the underwater mountains and hydrothermal vents of the deep-sea floor. ⁠
⁠
In “The Brilliant Abyss”, Helen Scales, a marine biologist, explores this rugged and shifting terrain.⁠
⁠
She writes about the plastic bags that have been spotted in the seven-mile-deep Mariana Trench. Nuclear waste, chemicals and oil spills have turned sections of sea floor into poisonous dumps.⁠
⁠
So what does Ms Scales think of deep-sea mining? Click on the link in our bio to read our review of her book, which covers the wonders, and threats, she finds in the deep.⁠
⁠
Credit: Nature Picture Library

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Middle East & Africa Syria has become a narco-state-but drugs are doing damage at home'.

node.text:
As the formal economy collapses under the burden of war, sanctions and the predatory rule of the Assads, the drug Captagon has become Syria’s main export and source of hard currency. ⁠
⁠
Syria has long been involved in drugs. But mass production within Syria began only after the civil war erupted in 2011. Officers gave Captagon to their fighters, calling it “Captain Courage”.⁠
⁠
Today the Assad regime may see Captagon pills as a lever in regional power struggles. For the Syrians left behind, drugs may destroy what remains of society after a decade of civil war. ⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read how the drug industry is shaping Syria.⁠
⁠
Credit: Abaca Press

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, sky and text that says 'Europe Climate change is affecting the flavour of wine'.

node.text:
According to Elizabeth Wolkovich, a biologist at the University of British Columbia, the impact of climate change on vineyards is rising. Temperatures are changing the taste of the wine itself.⁠
⁠
In cooler regions, warming conditions have allowed winemakers to grow more flavourful berries and enjoy longer growing seasons. However, warmer places like France, Italy and Spain have had a rotten deal.⁠
⁠
For some this presents an opportunity. Parts of Britain now have the perfect climate to make sparkling wines, throwing down the gauntlet to French champagne. ⁠
⁠
There's no time to lose. Tap the link in our bio to read why European winemakers need to plant more resilient and diverse varieties of vine. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Jeff Pachoud/AFP

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and text.

node.text:
India's second wave of covid has weakened an already fragile economy. Even as the virus recedes, its effects will linger for much longer.⁠
⁠
In the year that ended on March 31st India’s GDP shrank by 7.3%, more than any other big Asian economy. ⁠
⁠
The economic impact of the second wave that followed may not have been as devastating as the first, which hit India's poorest cruelly. But for many, the psychological shock of the second round has been harder.⁠
⁠
Tens of millions of middle-class Indians have found themselves tipped abruptly down the income ladder. Even those more comfortably off have had to dip into savings and put off investments.⁠
⁠
As richer countries begin to bounce back, India finds itself stuck with persistent unemployment and inflation, limp demand and falling savings and investment.⁠
⁠
If India’s post-covid economic troubles are due to anything, it is to a legacy of consistently poor choices by its leaders. Click the link in our bio to find out why.⁠
⁠
Credit: Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 19, 2021. May be an illustration.

node.text:
⁠Half a century on, the race to return to the Moon looks markedly different from the first US missions. ⁠
⁠
One of the goals of the Artemis programme, as NASA’s back-to-the-Moon programme is known, is to highlight the ways in which America has changed in the intervening decades. Another is to be comparatively cheap. ⁠
⁠
One thing remains the same, however.⁠
⁠
Artemis, like Apollo 11, is shaped by the geopolitics of great-power rivalry—then between America and the Soviet Union, now between America and China. ⁠
⁠
To read how China plans to become the leading power in space, through a mixture of its own perseverance and America’s decline, tap the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @elliefp

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 19, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and standing.

node.text:
Julia Ducournau has become the second woman ever to win top prize at the Cannes Film Festival. ⁠
⁠
“Titane” is only Ms Ducournau’s second feature film. But it is even more shocking than her debut. ⁠
⁠
The film’s anti-heroine, Alexia, is a tough, heavily tattooed and scarred young woman who makes a living by dancing for the lecherous patrons at motor shows. She is well qualified for the job because she has had an erotic obsession with cars ever since she was injured in a crash as a child. ⁠
⁠
What is even weirder is that cars reciprocate her feelings. When she discovers that she is pregnant with something oily and metallic, the film only gets more jaw-dropping. ⁠
⁠
Scene by scene, the dark narrative flows with a kind of logic, but it is impossible to guess where it is going. ⁠
⁠
Not many people at Cannes had expected “Titane” to win the Palme d’Or. But to read why in retrospect, any other choice would have been a disappointment, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Reuters/Sarah Meyssonnier

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 19, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and outdoors.

node.text:
“There’s no infrastructure, no schools, no hospitals, nothing—nothing except cannabis.”⁠
⁠
The Rif, a poor mountainous region in northern Morocco, grows most of the country's supply of cannabis. But farmers there operate in a legal grey area. ⁠
⁠
A new bill that would legalise the cultivation, use and export of cannabis for medical and industrial purposes, may clarify the situation somewhat. ⁠
⁠
Morocco's interior minister argues that the law will improve the lot of Riffians and free them from international drug-smuggling networks. It could also help the government tackle environmental damage caused by the soil degradation and deforestation associated with cannabis cultivation. ⁠
⁠
But many weed farmers in the Rif worry that the government is just blowing smoke. Tap the link in our bio to learn why.⁠
⁠
Credit: Fadel Senna/AFP via Getty Images

node.text:
Britain is one of just six countries to have enshrined its net-zero target in law. But achieving it won't be cheap. ⁠
⁠
Unmitigated climate change would be even more costly, however. If the Earth's average temperature were to rise by 4°C, the fiscal burden would be greater than either of the 20th century's world wars.⁠
⁠
Still, the spending on mitigation comes long before the benefits. Insulating a building, for example, involves an upfront cost, only later recouped in lower heating bills. ⁠
⁠
So far public opinion in Britain has been strongly in favour of the net-zero target. But to read why the politics could get tricky, click on the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'GOING FOR BOLD: OLYMPIC HISTORY IN EIGHT OUTFITS'.

node.text:
You can learn a lot about the Olympics by the outfits. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
At Mexico 1968, in a year of revolution, three African-American athletes wore outfits that resembled Black Panther uniforms (image 2). It spoke not of struggle, but victory.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In 1996 Michael Johnson asked Nike for a shoe with less of everything. The result was like a whisper of gold leaf (image 3). They seemed to allow him to rise, Mercury-like, into the air above the track. They were a rebellion against convention. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
At the 2008 games in Beijing, 98% of the victorious and record-breaking swimmers had something in common: the Speedo LZR. It turned the occupant into a frictionless, gold-grabbing flesh torpedo. The International Swimming Federation banned it. But then came the Fastskin (image 4) – a swimsuit that turns the body into the filling of a shiny hydrodynamic frankfurter.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Tap the link in our bio to discover how style changed sport.⁠⁠ From @1843mag 
⁠⁠
Credit: Getty Images

node.text:
Mutated viruses which survive and thrive are called variants.⁠
⁠
New variants must hold some advantage over old ones if they are to become the dominant form of the virus. That advantage could be won in many different ways, but for a respiratory disease like covid-19, one of the most important factors is transmissibility, how easily the virus passes from one person to another.⁠
⁠
Delta, the variant which was first detected in India and which is currently spreading around the world, appears to be even more transmissible than Alpha and the other variants.⁠
⁠
For another variant to outcompete Delta it will need new tricks. Click the link in our bio to read why. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Mike Kemp/In Pictures via Getty Images
